subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... consistent, ... don t ... I would give my left ...eye to have a New Zealander write in and say the chart is crazy wrong or the chart is spot on or
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> Okay. I compared the NZ chart to the American one. They seem
consistent,
> which is what we aimed for--the same letters take the same sets. I
don't
> know if a New Zealender would necessarily agree with the choices, of
> course; I have no idea about this accent.
>

I would give my left ...eye to have a New Zealander write in and say
"the chart is crazy wrong" or "the chart is spot on" or anything in
between.

Any southern hemisphere Anglophone: please ruthlessly criticize this
chart:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/new_zealand.jpg



> As you probably saw, I posted my own chart. We seem to be working at
> cross purposes. But, just having a look at your chart again, I see we
> are pretty much in complete agreement with the exception that
>

My chart is derived from yours and the posts up to this point
capturing (I hope) prose explanations with graphics. Where mine
differs then it is either something to discuss further or it is an
error on my part.


Speaking of which...

re:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/typical_us.jpg

> you put LOT under Ah, whereas I put it under On and added an
explanation at the
> end as to what users should do when merging Ah Awl and On.
>

An interesting point:

GA
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_back_unrounded_vowel

Bostonian
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_back_rounded_vowel

Now what do we do when LOT merges with PALM, write them both with Ah
or Ox? If we're going with lexical sets we're gonna have to choose one
for all accents.

The latest rule was "...We can unambiguously write...PALM with Ah..."
which favors GA. In this case a Bostonian treats #32Ah as sampa [Q] and GA
treats it as [A:] Same QS letter but different sound.

The alternative might be "We can unambiguously write LOT with Ox"
which is pro Boston but nothing really changes, the same letter will
have different sounds in different accents.

My mistake at the least was to put the [Q] IPA symbol above #32Ah
which I will now fix.



> If I'm not mistaken, the biggest problem facing us right now is what to
> do with mergers. I don't hear the difference between "beer" and "bear,"
> so how do I write this word? Do I write it as I hear it,

If so, which letter does one use use? I believe one would do this:
-look up "even" and "ever" in the Cambridge dictionary to find the
phoneme Read meant for #27Eat and #28Et
-look up "beer" and "bear" in a Bostonian dictionary (humor me here)
to find the phoneme that you personally use.
-use the corresponding QS letter.

Luckily this will work for Boston with it's minimal vowel shift.
Unluckily it may be hard for a southern hemisphere Anglophone to use
this technique. And obviously it circumvents lexical sets.


>but for more
> formal writing look up its *pronounciation* (not spelling!) in a
> standard dictionary?

Having everyday writing differ from formal writing feels very, very
yucky to me. But one way to do this is to look up words in Cambridge
(Read's accent) and spell according to the pronunciation it describes
(plus rules for Roe etc). Spelling in formal writing would thus be
standardized to Kingsley Read (ie RP). While I think this would work,
I'm not sure I like it one bit.





> > >
> > > "Kyor?" That couldn't be anything but "cure", so I wouldn't have
> > trouble
> > > with it.
> >
> > But is this a significant improvement over Et+Key+See+Et+No+Tea for
> > "accent". I'm not being glib, it is an important question: I want to
> > make sure we are not trading known problems for unknown ones.
>
> Wouldn't you actually write it Kick Yo-yo Wool Roar? That is exactly as
> I hear it.

With lexical sets, as a result of mergers, "cure" will be spelled
three different ways (ie Yoyo + Awe/Foot/Ooze + Roar ) This is
expected and is likely an improvement over straight phoneme to letter
assignment.

But if we find spelling variation that can not be attributed to a
lexical set merger (maybe "pin" & "pen" or "kit" & "utter") then we
know there is some hidden behavior in our system. We would want to
explicitly locate it and understand it and make sure it doesn't make
things unworkable in some area.



> I'll not do any more work on my chart, since yours reflect a deeper
> understanding and we seem to have produced nearly the same chart anyway.
>


Please don't stop on my account. It is much easier for me to
understand these ideas when accompanied by uploads: it can be
enormously difficult to follow a long prose post in and of itself but
combined with two ways to write IPA in ascii, two names for every
letter and no graphics or unicode characters it very nearly makes my
brain bleed.
I don't think we should view any uploads as final yet: you may have
noticed that I'm just slamming jpg screen shots up.
